result.markdown:
--- title: "Directed Acyclic Graphs" --- # Assignment ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### Task 1: - This seems to be similar to the Confounding DAG explained in the theory. The *parking spots* seems to be the treatment variable and *store sales* would be the outcome variable. The confounding variable would be the *location*, as it makes a difference to the store sales if the location of the store is the city center or in the Urban areas. ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_6a7e8752d3cabc8dc579a9602459fe73'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Loading Libraries library(tidyverse) library(dagitty) library(ggdag) # Define the DAG dag <- dagify( X ~ Z, Y ~ Z, X ~ Y, coords = list(x = c(Y = 3, Z = 2, X = 1), y = c(Y = 0, Z = 1, X = 0)), labels = list(X = "Sales", Y = "Parking Spots", Z = "Location") ) ggdag(dag) + theme_dag() + geom_dag_point() + geom_dag_text() + geom_dag_edges() + geom_dag_label_repel(aes(label = label)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](05_dag_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Task 2: > Loading the customer_sat data set ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_535f04ac6199e0da2da2fa285a687bcb'} ```{.r .cell-code} df_customer_sat <- readRDS("../../Causal_Data_Science_Data/customer_sat.rds") head(df_customer_sat) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: 1. Regress `satisfaction` on `follow_ups` ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_0c2c1b94fc28828c9eb68b4356159622'} ```{.r .cell-code} lm_model1 <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = df_customer_sat) ``` ::: > Summary ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_2b2a6a08bd4809172547041ff501e394'} ```{.r .cell-code} summary(lm_model1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> #> Call: #> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = df_customer_sat) #> #> Residuals: #> Min 1Q Median 3Q Max #> -12.412 -5.257 1.733 4.506 12.588 #> #> Coefficients: #> Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) #> (Intercept) 78.8860 4.2717 18.467 1.04e-10 *** #> follow_ups -3.3093 0.6618 -5.001 0.000243 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #> #> Residual standard error: 7.923 on 13 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared: 0.658, Adjusted R-squared: 0.6316 #> F-statistic: 25.01 on 1 and 13 DF, p-value: 0.0002427 ``` ::: ::: 2. Regress `satisfaction` on `follow_ups` and account for `subscription` ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_37683e201526b3994f2522d830ef3d76'} ```{.r .cell-code} df_customer_sat$subscription <- as.factor(df_customer_sat$subscription) lm_model_2 <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = df_customer_sat) ``` ::: > Summary ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_ef94649dadcf515f5974f8b97fd9aef1'} ```{.r .cell-code} summary(lm_model_2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> #> Call: #> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = df_customer_sat) #> #> Residuals: #> Min 1Q Median 3Q Max #> -4.3222 -2.1972 0.3167 2.2667 3.9944 #> #> Coefficients: #> Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) #> (Intercept) 26.7667 6.6804 4.007 0.00206 ** #> follow_ups 2.1944 0.7795 2.815 0.01682 * #> subscriptionPremium 44.7222 5.6213 7.956 6.88e-06 *** #> subscriptionPremium+ 18.0722 2.1659 8.344 4.37e-06 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #> #> Residual standard error: 2.958 on 11 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared: 0.9597, Adjusted R-squared: 0.9487 #> F-statistic: 87.21 on 3 and 11 DF, p-value: 5.956e-08 ``` ::: ::: ### Task 3: - For the model *without a subscription,* the coefficient is *-3.3093*. This negative coefficient indicates that without a subscription, follow ups decrease the satisfaction level of the customers - For the model *with a subscription, the coefficient is **2.1944.* This positive coefficient indicates that with a subscription, follows_ups increases the satisfaction level of the customers. *Premium* coefficient is +44.7222, indicating that being on this subscription level is associated with a 44.7222 point increase in satisfaction compared to the base category. *Elite* coefficient is +18.0722, indicating that being on this subscription level is associated with an 18.0722 point increase in satisfaction compared to the base category. - I believe customers find it intrusive when they are being followed up without any subscription. They probablyy have fewers features as well, so this might be the cause for the negative impact. On the other hand, the premium and elite customers find it better with the follow ups. - As mentioned in the previous point, a similar impact is also seen on the variance R^2^ and R^2^ (Adjusted). Both the values increased, as the model now captures more of the variance in satisfaction. This makes subscription level an important factor in explaining customer satisfaction. ### Task 4: ::: {.cell hash='05_dag_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_227a4dabfc4ab165a71b3759987730fa'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Define the DAG dag_customer_satisfaction <- dagify( Z ~ X, Z ~ Y, Y ~ X, coords = list(x = c(Y = 3, Z = 2, X = 1), y = c(Y = 0, Z = 1, X = 0)), labels = list(X = "Subscription ", Y = "Follow_ups", Z = "Satisfaction") ) ggdag(dag_customer_satisfaction) + theme_dag() + geom_dag_point() + geom_dag_text() + geom_dag_edges() + geom_dag_label_repel(aes(label = label)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](05_dag_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: :::
